metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Girls and Women, a practical guide to conduct published in 1890 by Harriet Eliza Paine, an American writer.
main_question:
I do not think that an ardent girl who loves music art, and poetry, and who hates history and science and mathematics, will ever quite do herself justice if she carries on all three of her favorite studies and ignores the others, even though her favorites are most essential to culture. I think, however, that though mathematics cannot be spared from the foundation of an education, it yields less culture on the whole to students who have no taste for it than any other study, [masked clause describing an inference or effect]. A friend says we must all be one-sided, so that perhaps our best chance is to have one hobby at a time and ride that to death, and then try another, becoming at last two, three, or four-sided, though never completely rounded.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing an inference or effect]:
answer_strings: so I do not advocate carrying it far, but history or some science would be a good counterpoise for a mind given to the study of beauty alone
so I recommend pushing it further, but history and every science would be an excellent match for a mind inclined towards studying beauty exclusively
so the rich must humbly try to take their place
as students who do not have any taste or interest in them will not be able to fully appreciate their importance and potential contributions
they will thus be deprived of the broader cultural benefits that a more balanced education would afford
passage: I do not think that an ardent girl who loves music art, and poetry, and who hates history and science and mathematics, will ever quite do herself justice if she carries on all three of her favorite studies and ignores the others, even though her favorites are most essential to culture. I think, however, that though mathematics cannot be spared from the foundation of an education, it yields less culture on the whole to students who have no taste for it than any other study, so I do not advocate carrying it far, but history or some science would be a good counterpoise for a mind given to the study of beauty alone. A friend says we must all be one-sided, so that perhaps our best chance is to have one hobby at a time and ride that to death, and then try another, becoming at last two, three, or four-sided, though never completely rounded.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Girls and Women, a practical guide to conduct published in 1890 by Harriet Eliza Paine, an American writer.
main_question:
Some one gives this good rule, "Decide when you ought to rise to make the best use of your day. Make a point of rising at that time; but go to bed earlier and earlier till you find out how much sleep you need in order to be fresh at that hour in the morning." Such a rule would meet most cases, but not all; [masked clause describing a cause or reason]. I would give more flexible rules, though it is harder to keep flexible rules than iron ones.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a cause or reason]:
answer_strings: for though regularity is as important for health as for a wise life, it cannot be an iron regularity, especially if a girl is at all delicate
for while irregularity may harm both physical and mental well-being, it need not be rigidly avoided, particularly if a girl is robust
because an extra hour in the morning can be better used than one later in the day, and if duties crowd you get tired in remembering what you cannot do
because it will give you an outlook beyond the daily horizon, and take your thoughts from your own weariness
for it should be modified if one has a child with colic or an elderly person under their care who requires night-time attention
because people’s sleep needs and daily obligations vary widely, making a fixed wake time unsuitable for everyone
passage: Some one gives this good rule, "Decide when you ought to rise to make the best use of your day. Make a point of rising at that time; but go to bed earlier and earlier till you find out how much sleep you need in order to be fresh at that hour in the morning." Such a rule would meet most cases, but not all; for though regularity is as important for health as for a wise life, it cannot be an iron regularity, especially if a girl is at all delicate. I would give more flexible rules, though it is harder to keep flexible rules than iron ones.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Girls and Women, a practical guide to conduct published in 1890 by Harriet Eliza Paine, an American writer.
main_question:
She was ready to pour out money in any case of distress, but she had no idea of its value, and none of her charities prospered, except so far as her rosy, good-natured face could be seen, for that, to be sure, did good like a medicine. And she was not a stupid girl, [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]. If she had been taught that arithmetic is positively needed by every girl, rich or poor, she could have learned all she needed to know of figures to make her life a blessing to hundreds of people whom she only injured for lack of such knowledge.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]:
answer_strings: though certainly not brilliant in mathematics
though hardly dull-witted in mathematics
though it was always a sorrow to her that she had had too little instruction to produce anything of value to others
though she was often ashamed of her cowardice
though she had been endowed with good common sense
though she lacked mathematical training, she was otherwise earnest in her benevolence
passage: She was ready to pour out money in any case of distress, but she had no idea of its value, and none of her charities prospered, except so far as her rosy, good-natured face could be seen, for that, to be sure, did good like a medicine. And she was not a stupid girl, though certainly not brilliant in mathematics. If she had been taught that arithmetic is positively needed by every girl, rich or poor, she could have learned all she needed to know of figures to make her life a blessing to hundreds of people whom she only injured for lack of such knowledge.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Girls and Women, a practical guide to conduct published in 1890 by Harriet Eliza Paine, an American writer.
main_question:
She has perhaps too great a scorn of receiving help from anybody. She once acted as a substitute in school for a friend who was ill. The obliged friend insisted that she should receive the ten dollars which would otherwise have been paid to herself. [masked sentence revising an implied expectation] I know of no one who acts more thoroughly on the rule, "If you have but sixpence to spend, spend it like a prince, and not like a beggar.” She is a true lover of nature, without pretense or cant of any kind.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence revising an implied expectation]:
answer_strings: But the independent young lady instantly took the money and invested it all in a beautiful piece of lace which she sent as a present to the convalescent.
But the dependent young lady instantly rejected the money and spent none on a beautiful piece of lace which she refused to send as a gift.

Nevertheless, her bills amounted to one sixth of the yearly income of the family, so that she never gave another party till later in life, when fortune suddenly smiled upon her again and put her in possession of a million.
But if she does a tithe as much for the poor she is likely to get some thanks, more or less sincere, and all her circle of friends admire her.
However, she refused to accept it, believing that she had no right to be paid for doing something that was not out of the ordinary.
Nevertheless, I declined the ten dollars, feeling that accepting such a gift would betray my principles of self‑reliance; true virtue, I believe, resides in refusing even sincere aid.
passage: She has perhaps too great a scorn of receiving help from anybody. She once acted as a substitute in school for a friend who was ill. The obliged friend insisted that she should receive the ten dollars which would otherwise have been paid to herself. But the independent young lady instantly took the money and invested it all in a beautiful piece of lace which she sent as a present to the convalescent. I know of no one who acts more thoroughly on the rule, "If you have but sixpence to spend, spend it like a prince, and not like a beggar.” She is a true lover of nature, without pretense or cant of any kind.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Girls and Women, a practical guide to conduct published in 1890 by Harriet Eliza Paine, an American writer.
main_question:
If, in the end, a girl marries, her reading and cooking and housekeeping are all necessary. How can she use these homely accomplishments in earning a living? They will not, to be sure, bring her a large income, but there is a steadier demand for good work in these directions than in any others. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]:
answer_strings: So a woman who has them is almost sure of a modest support.
So a woman who lacks them is sure of a modest support.

Of course she may thus in time be fitted for higher work, and she may prefer to do it, and may even earn more money by it, but she will then do the work because it is her natural choice and not for the sake of the money."
She will find that her husband and family will benefit from her skills to maintain a happy home.
Consequently, she can earn a modest but steady wage by offering her cooking, housekeeping, and reading skills to families who require such assistance.
passage: If, in the end, a girl marries, her reading and cooking and housekeeping are all necessary. How can she use these homely accomplishments in earning a living? They will not, to be sure, bring her a large income, but there is a steadier demand for good work in these directions than in any others. So a woman who has them is almost sure of a modest support.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Girls and Women, a practical guide to conduct published in 1890 by Harriet Eliza Paine, an American writer.
main_question:
Both these influences have a noble source, and will probably reach more beautiful results at last. Any mind awake to beauty must try to create it, and if its power and originality are not very great, what can it do better than to apply itself to humble, every-day trifles and try to decorate them? This is certainly right, [masked clause describing a condition or proviso]: "Decorate construction, do not construct decoration." A few illustrations of my meaning may be needed.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a condition or proviso]:
answer_strings: if the old principle of architecture is always remembered
if the old principle of architecture is ever forgotten
unless the circumstances are of a very unusual character
provided it is done with sincerity and an understanding of form
provided that the decoration remains modest and serves the purpose of the piece
passage: Both these influences have a noble source, and will probably reach more beautiful results at last. Any mind awake to beauty must try to create it, and if its power and originality are not very great, what can it do better than to apply itself to humble, every-day trifles and try to decorate them? This is certainly right, if the old principle of architecture is always remembered: "Decorate construction, do not construct decoration." A few illustrations of my meaning may be needed.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Girls and Women, a practical guide to conduct published in 1890 by Harriet Eliza Paine, an American writer.
main_question:
She was among the most skillful physicians of her native city. She saved many lives, and relieved much suffering. She gave her priceless services to hundreds of poor people, but she did not give to those who could pay for them. I think she was altogether right. [masked sentence describing a cause or reason] Perhaps she blocked the way of less fortunate physicians.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing a cause or reason]:
answer_strings: The world was better because she used her gift, and she was happier, as all are who exercise their powers.
The world was worse because she squandered her gift, and she was unhappier, as all are who neglect their powers.
It was because she could give priceless services that she had so clear a right to fix a price which she did not need.
Her renunciation comes partly because she loves those for whom she makes the sacrifice, but partly also from cowardice.
She believed that those who could afford medical care should support their local doctors financially.
She believed that medicine should be a universal right, not a commodity.
passage: She was among the most skillful physicians of her native city. She saved many lives, and relieved much suffering. She gave her priceless services to hundreds of poor people, but she did not give to those who could pay for them. I think she was altogether right. The world was better because she used her gift, and she was happier, as all are who exercise their powers. Perhaps she blocked the way of less fortunate physicians.
